title.rendered: How will you know in GIT if a branch has been already merged into master?

content.rendered:
Git branch—merged lists the branches that have been merged into the current branch

Git branch—-no merged lists the branches that have not been merged

excerpt.rendered: Git branch—merged lists the branches that have been merged into the current branch Git branch—-no merged lists the branches that have not been merged

title.rendered: What is a repository in GIT?

content.rendered: A repository contains a directory named .git, where git keeps all of its metadata for the repository. The content of the .git directory are private to git.

excerpt.rendered: A repository contains a directory named .git, where git keeps all of its metadata for the repository. The content of the .git directory are private to git.

title.rendered: What is the command you can use to write a commit message?

content.rendered: The command that is used to write a commit message is “git commit –a”.  The –a on the command line instructs git to commit the new content of all tracked files that have been modified. You can use “git add<file>” before git commit –a if new files need to be committed for the first time.

excerpt.rendered: The command that is used to write a commit message is “git commit –a”.  The –a on the command line instructs git to commit the new content of all tracked files that have been modified. You can use “git add<file>” before git commit –a if new files need to be committed for the first time.

title.rendered: What is the difference between GIT and SVN?

content.rendered:
The difference between GIT and SVN is

a) Git is less preferred for handling extremely large files or frequently changing binary files while SVN can handle multiple projects stored in the same repository.

b) GIT does not support ‘commits’ across multiple branches or tags.  Subversion allows the creation of folders at any location in the repository layout.

c) Gits are unchangeable, while Subversion allows committers to treat a tag as a branch and to create multiple revisions under a tag root.

excerpt.rendered: The difference between GIT and SVN is a) Git is less preferred for handling extremely large files or frequently changing binary files while SVN can handle multiple projects stored in the same repository. b) GIT does not support ‘commits’ across multiple branches or tags.  Subversion allows the creation of folders at any location in the repository layout. […]

title.rendered: What are the advantages of using GIT?

content.rendered:
a) Data redundancy and replication

b) High availability

c) Only one.git directory per repository

d) Superior disk utilization and network performance

e) Collaboration friendly

f) Any sort of projects can use GIT

excerpt.rendered: a) Data redundancy and replication b) High availability c) Only one.git directory per repository d) Superior disk utilization and network performance e) Collaboration friendly f) Any sort of projects can use GIT

title.rendered: What language is used in GIT?

content.rendered: GIT is fast, and ‘C’ language makes this possible by reducing the overhead of runtimes associated with higher languages.

excerpt.rendered: GIT is fast, and ‘C’ language makes this possible by reducing the overhead of runtimes associated with higher languages.

title.rendered: What is the function of ‘GIT PUSH’ in GIT?

content.rendered: ‘GIT PUSH’ updates remote refs along with associated objects.

excerpt.rendered: ‘GIT PUSH’ updates remote refs along with associated objects.

title.rendered: Why GIT better than Subversion?

content.rendered: GIT is an open source version control system; it will allow you to run ‘versions’ of a project, which show the changes that were made to the code overtime also it allows you keep the backtrack if necessary and undo those changes. Multiple developers can checkout, and upload changes and each change can then be attributed to a specific developer.

excerpt.rendered: GIT is an open source version control system; it will allow you to run ‘versions’ of a project, which show the changes that were made to the code overtime also it allows you keep the backtrack if necessary and undo those changes. Multiple developers can checkout, and upload changes and each change can then be […]

title.rendered: What is “Staging Area” or “Index” in GIT?

content.rendered: Before completing the commits, it can be formatted and reviewed in an intermediate area known as ‘Staging Area’ or ‘Index’.

excerpt.rendered: Before completing the commits, it can be formatted and reviewed in an intermediate area known as ‘Staging Area’ or ‘Index’.

title.rendered: What is GIT stash?

content.rendered: GIT stash takes the current state of the working directory and index and puts in on the stack for later and gives you back a clean working directory.  So in case if you are in the middle of something and need to jump over to the other job, and at the same time you don’t want to lose your current edits then you can use GIT stash.

excerpt.rendered: GIT stash takes the current state of the working directory and index and puts in on the stack for later and gives you back a clean working directory.  So in case if you are in the middle of something and need to jump over to the other job, and at the same time you don’t […]

title.rendered: What is GIT stash drop?

content.rendered: When you are done with the stashed item or want to remove it from the list, run the git ‘stash drop’ command.  It will remove the last added stash item by default, and it can also remove a specific item if you include as an argument.

excerpt.rendered: When you are done with the stashed item or want to remove it from the list, run the git ‘stash drop’ command.  It will remove the last added stash item by default, and it can also remove a specific item if you include as an argument.

title.rendered: What is the function of git clone?

content.rendered: The git clone command creates a copy of an existing Git repository.  To get the copy of a central repository, ‘cloning’  is the most common way used by programmers.

excerpt.rendered: The git clone command creates a copy of an existing Git repository.  To get the copy of a central repository, ‘cloning’  is the most common way used by programmers.

title.rendered: What is the function of ‘git config’?

content.rendered: The ‘git config’ command is a convenient way to set configuration options for your Git installation.  Behaviour of a repository, user info, preferences etc. can be defined through this command.

excerpt.rendered: The ‘git config’ command is a convenient way to set configuration options for your Git installation.  Behaviour of a repository, user info, preferences etc. can be defined through this command.

title.rendered: 16) How can you create a repository in Git?

content.rendered: In Git, to create a repository, create a directory for the project if it does not exist, and then run command “git init”. By running this command .git directory will be created in the project directory, the directory does not need to be empty.

excerpt.rendered: In Git, to create a repository, create a directory for the project if it does not exist, and then run command “git init”. By running this command .git directory will be created in the project directory, the directory does not need to be empty.

title.rendered: What is the common branching pattern in GIT?

content.rendered:
The common way of creating branch in GIT is to maintain one as “Main“

branch and create another branch to implement new features. This pattern is particularly useful when there are multiple developers working on a single project.

excerpt.rendered: The common way of creating branch in GIT is to maintain one as “Main“ branch and create another branch to implement new features. This pattern is particularly useful when there are multiple developers working on a single project.

title.rendered: What is ‘head’ in git and how many heads can be created in a repository?

content.rendered: A ‘head’ is simply a reference to a commit object. In every repository, there is a default head referred as “Master”.  A repository can contain any number of heads.

excerpt.rendered: A ‘head’ is simply a reference to a commit object. In every repository, there is a default head referred as “Master”.  A repository can contain any number of heads.

title.rendered: What is the purpose of branching in GIT?

content.rendered: The purpose of branching in GIT is that you can create your own branch and jump between those branches. It will allow you to go to your previous work keeping your recent work intact.

excerpt.rendered: The purpose of branching in GIT is that you can create your own branch and jump between those branches. It will allow you to go to your previous work keeping your recent work intact.

title.rendered: What does commit object contain?

content.rendered:
a) A set of files, representing the state of a project at a given point of time

b) Reference to parent commit objects

c) An SHAI name, a 40 character string that uniquely identifies the commit object.

excerpt.rendered: a) A set of files, representing the state of a project at a given point of time b) Reference to parent commit objects c) An SHAI name, a 40 character string that uniquely identifies the commit object.

title.rendered: How can you bring a new feature in the main branch?

content.rendered: To bring a new feature in the main branch, you can use a command “git merge” or “git pull command”.

excerpt.rendered: To bring a new feature in the main branch, you can use a command “git merge” or “git pull command”.

title.rendered: What is a ‘conflict’ in git?

content.rendered: A ‘conflict’ arises when the commit that has to be merged has some change in one place, and the current commit also has a change at the same place. Git will not be able to predict which change should take precedence.

excerpt.rendered: A ‘conflict’ arises when the commit that has to be merged has some change in one place, and the current commit also has a change at the same place. Git will not be able to predict which change should take precedence.
